remarks: If two metrics are strongly equivalent, one is complete iff the other is.  Unlike ~ equivcau , ~ metss2 , this theorem does not have a one-directional form - it is possible for a metric ` C ` that is strongly finer than the complete metric ` D ` to be incomplete and vice versa.  Consider ` D = ` the metric on ` RR ` induced by the usual homeomorphism from ` ( 0 , 1 ) ` against the usual metric ` C ` on ` RR ` and against the discrete metric ` E ` on ` RR ` .  Then both ` C ` and ` E ` are complete but ` D ` is not, and ` C ` is strongly finer than ` D ` , which is strongly finer than ` E ` .  (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 15-Sep-2015.)
statement:
equivcmet.1 $e |- ( ph -> C e. ( Met ` X ) ) $.
equivcmet.2 $e |- ( ph -> D e. ( Met ` X ) ) $.
equivcmet.3 $e |- ( ph -> R e. RR+ ) $.
equivcmet.4 $e |- ( ph -> S e. RR+ ) $.
equivcmet.5 $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( x e. X /\ y e. X ) ) -> ( x C y ) <_ ( R x. ( x D y ) ) ) $.
equivcmet.6 $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( x e. X /\ y e. X ) ) -> ( x D y ) <_ ( S x. ( x C y ) ) ) $.
equivcmet $p |- ( ph -> ( C e. ( CMet ` X ) <-> D e. ( CMet ` X ) ) ) $.
